19:28 • 21 days ago

Simon Willison

LLM can now be installed directly from Homebrew

LLM can now be installed directly from Homebrew I spent a bunch of time on this at the weekend: my LLM tool for interacting with large language models from the terminal has now been accepted into Homebrew core, and can be installed directly using "brew install llm". I was previously running my own separate tap, but having it in core means that it benefits from Homebrew's impressive set of build

LLM can now be installed directly from Homebrew

I spent a bunch of time on this at the weekend: my LLM tool for interacting with large language models from the terminal has now been accepted into Homebrew core, and can be installed directly using "brew install llm". I was previously running my own separate tap, but having it in core means that it benefits from Homebrew's impressive set of build systems - each release of LLM now has Bottles created for it automatically across a range of platforms, so "brew install llm" should quickly download binary assets rather than spending several minutes installing dependencies the slow way.

Via Issue: Submit LLM to Homebrew

17:16 • 21 days ago

sqlite-utils now supports plugins

sqlite-utils 3.34 is out with a major new feature: support for plugins. sqlite-utils is my combination Python library and command-line tool for manipulating SQLite databases. It recently celebrated its fifth birthday, and has had over 100 releases since it first launched back in 2018. The new plugin system is inspired by similar mechanisms in Datasette and LLM. It lets developers add new featu

sqlite-utils 3.34 is out with a major new feature: support for plugins.

sqlite-utils is my combination Python library and command-line tool for manipulating SQLite databases. It recently celebrated its fifth birthday, and has had over 100 releases since it first launched back in 2018.

The new plugin system is inspired by similar mechanisms in Datasette and LLM. It lets developers add new features to sqlite-utils without needing to get their changes accepted by the core project.

I love plugin systems. As an open source maintainer they are by far the best way to encourage people to contribute to my projects - I can genuinely wake up in the morning and my software has new features, and I didn't even need to review a pull request.

Plugins also offer a fantastic medium for exploration and experimentation. I can try out new ideas without committing to supporting them in core, and without needing to tie improvements to them to the core release cycle.

Version 3.34 adds two initial plugin hooks: register_commands() and prepare_connection(). These are both based on the equivalent hooks in Datasette.

I planned to just ship register_commands(), but Alex Garcia spotted my activity on the repo and submitted a PR adding prepare_connection() literally minutes before I had intended to ship the release!

register_commands()

The register_commands() hook lets you add new commands to the sqlite-utils command-line tool - so users can run sqlite-utils your-new-command to access your feature.

I've learned from past experience that you should never ship a plugin hook without also releasing at least one plugin that uses it. I've built two so far for register_commands():

sqlite-utils-shell adds a simply interactive shell, accessed using sqlite-utils shell for an in-memory database or sqlite-utils shell data.db to run it against a specific database file. sqlite-migrate is my first draft of a database migrations system for SQLite, loosely inspired by Django migrations and previewed by the migration mechanism I added to LLM.

Try out the shell plugin like this:

sqlite-utils install sqlite-utils-shell sqlite-utils shell

The interface looks like this:

In-memory database, content will be lost on exit Type 'exit' to exit. sqlite-utils> select 3 + 5; 3 + 5 ------- 8 sqlite-utils> prepare_connection()

This hook, contributed by Alex, lets you modify the connection object before it is used to execute any SQL. Most importantly, this lets you register custom SQLite functions.

I expect this to be the most common category of plugin. I've built one so far: sqlite-utils-dateutil, which adds functions for parsing dates and times using the dateutil library.

It lets you do things like this:

sqlite-utils install sqlite-utils-dateutil sqlite-utils memory "select dateutil_parse('3rd october')" -t

Output:

dateutil_parse('3rd october') ------------------------------- 2023-10-03T00:00:00

This works inside sqlite-shell too.

Plugins that you install also become available in the Python API interface to sqlite-utils:

>>> import sqlite_utils >>> db = sqlite_utils.Database(memory=True) >>> list(db.query("select dateutil_parse('3rd october')")) [{"dateutil_parse('3rd october')": '2023-10-03T00:00:00'}]

You can opt out of executing installed plugins by passing execute_plugins=False to the Database() constructor:

>>> db = sqlite_utils.Database(memory=True, execute_plugins=False) >>> list(db.query("select dateutil_parse('3rd october')")) Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> File ".../site-packages/sqlite_utils/db.py", line 494, in query cursor = self.execute(sql, params or tuple()) File ".../site-packages/sqlite_utils/db.py", line 512, in execute return self.conn.execute(sql, parameters) sqlite3.OperationalError: no such function: dateutil_parse sqlite-ml by Romain Clement

I quietly released sqlite-utils 3.34 on Saturday. The community has already released several plugins for it!

Romain Clement built sqlite-utils-ml, a plugin wrapper for his sqlite-ml project.

This adds custom SQL functions for training machine learning models and running predictions, entirely within SQLite, using algorithms from scikit-learn.

Here's what that looks like running inside sqlite-utils shell:

sqlite-utils install sqlite-utils-shell sqlite-utils-ml sqlite-utils shell ml.db Attached to ml.db Type 'exit' to exit. sqlite-utils> select sqml_load_dataset('iris') as dataset; dataset -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- {"table": "dataset_iris", "feature_names": ["sepal length (cm)", "sepal width (cm)", "petal length (cm)", "petal width (cm)"], "target_names": ["setosa", "versicolor", "virginica"], "size": 150} sqlite-utils> select sqml_train( ...> 'Iris prediction', ...> 'classification', ...> 'logistic_regression', ...> 'dataset_iris', ...> 'target' ...> ) as training; training -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- {"experiment_name": "Iris prediction", "prediction_type": "classification", "algorithm": "logistic_regression", "deployed": true, "score": 0.9736842105263158} sqlite-utils> select ...> dataset_iris.*, ...> sqml_predict( ...> 'Iris prediction', ...> json_object( ...> 'sepal length (cm)', [sepal length (cm)], ...> 'sepal width (cm)', [sepal width (cm)], ...> 'petal length (cm)', [petal length (cm)], ...> 'petal width (cm)', [petal width (cm)] ...> ) ...> ) as prediction ...> from dataset_iris ...> limit 1; sepal length (cm) sepal width (cm) petal length (cm) petal width (cm) target prediction ------------------- ------------------ ------------------- ------------------ -------- ------------ 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 0 0 SQLite extensions by Alex Garcia

Alex Garcia has a growing collection of SQLite extensions, many of which are written in Rust but are packaged as wheels for ease of installation using Python.

Alex released five plugins for SQLite corresponding to five of his existing extensions:

sqlite-utils-sqlite-regex sqlite-utils-sqlite-path sqlite-utils-sqlite-url sqlite-utils-sqlite-ulid sqlite-utils-sqlite-lines

Here's an example of sqlite-utils-sqlite-ulid in action:

sqlite-utils install sqlite-utils-sqlite-ulid sqlite-utils memory 'select ulid() u1, ulid() u2, ulid() u3' | jq

Output:

[ { "u1": "01h64d1ysg1rx63z1gwy7nah4n", "u2": "01h64d1ysgd7vx04sc9pncqh10", "u3": "01h64d1ysgz1sy7njkqt86dkq9" } ]

I've started a sqlite-utils plugin directory with a list of all of the plugins so far.

Building your own plugin

If you want to try building your own plugin, the documentation includes a simple step-by-step guide. A plugin can be built with as little as two files: a Python module implementing the hooks, and a pyproject.toml module with metadata about how it should be installed.

I've also released a new cookiecutter template: simonw/sqlite-utils-plugin. Here's how to use that to get started building a plugin:

cookiecutter gh:simonw/sqlite-utils-plugin

Answer the form fields like this:

plugin_name []: rot13 description []: select rot13('text') as a sqlite-utils plugin hyphenated [rot13]: underscored [rot13]: github_username []: your-username author_name []: your-name

Change directory into the new folder and use sqlite-utils install -e to install an editable version of your plugin, so changes you make will be reflected when you run the tool:

cd sqlite-utils-rot13 sqlite-utils install -e .

Run this command to confirm the plugin has been installed:

sqlite-utils plugins

You should see this:

[ { "name": "sqlite-utils-rot13", "hooks": [ "prepare_connection" ], "version": "0.1" } ]

Now drop this code into the sqlite_utils_rot13.py file:

import sqlite_utils def rot13(s): chars = [] for v in s: c = ord(v) if c >= ord("a") and c <= ord("z"): if c > ord("m"): c -= 13 else: c += 13 elif c >= ord("A") and c <= ord("Z"): if c > ord("M"): c -= 13 else: c += 13 chars.append(chr(c)) return "".join(chars) @sqlite_utils.hookimpl def prepare_connection(conn): conn.create_function("rot13", 1, rot13)

And try it out like this:

sqlite-utils memory "select rot13('hello world')"

Output:

[{"rot13('hello world')": "uryyb jbeyq"}]

And to reverse that:

sqlite-utils memory "select rot13('uryyb jbeyq')"

Output:

[{"rot13('uryyb jbeyq')": "hello world"}]

As you can see, building plugins can be done with very little code. I'm excited to see what else people build with this new capability!

17:06 • 21 days ago

Sunday, 23. July 2023

Jon Udell

Is there an early warning system for RSI?

My RSI (repetitive strain injury) struggles began 25 years ago, after an intensive push to build and ship the BYTE magazine website. The tendons in both wrists became badly inflamed, and I spent a couple of months in rehab: anti-inflammatory meds, alternating heat and ice, stretching. It mostly resolved, but my left thumb joint remained â€¦ Continue reading Is there an early warning system for RSI?

My RSI (repetitive strain injury) struggles began 25 years ago, after an intensive push to build and ship the BYTE magazine website. The tendons in both wrists became badly inflamed, and I spent a couple of months in rehab: anti-inflammatory meds, alternating heat and ice, stretching. It mostly resolved, but my left thumb joint remained painful. One day, as I wondered what could possibly be the cause, I looked down at my hands as I was typing. I use the worldâ€™s best (and rarest) split keyboard so thereâ€™s a left spacebar and a right spacebar. Suddenly it was obvious. I was always hitting the left spacebar with my left thumb, an unconscious habit that was repeated hundreds or thousands of times a day. And I was really slamming it too, another habit that I still have to monitor. Thus began one of a series of interventions to remap the relationship between fingers and keys. In that case, I assigned my right thumb to the spacebar, intending to switch to an alternating pattern once things settled down. All these years later, I look down at my hands now and see that never happened. Iâ€™m still using the right spacebar exclusively. I should probably try to change that, but thereâ€™s a more pressing problem.

Over the years, I got bitten a few more times by the effects of asymmetry. When my left hand became painful again, I realized I was mousing exclusively with that hand, and switched the mouse to my right side. I think Iâ€™ve gone back and forth a few times, currently itâ€™s again on the right.

Another time, when I was doing a lot of lap swimming, my right shoulder became painful. Once again, it was something that should have been obvious, but wasnâ€™t to the medical people I consulted, and wasnâ€™t to me either until, once again, I recognized another asymmetry: I was always breathing on the left side, which put extra strain on the right shoulder. When I switched to an alternating pattern, breathing every third stroke instead of every second, that problem resolved.

Youâ€™d think Iâ€™d have learned my lesson by now. But when the knuckle of my left pinky suddenly became inflamed two months ago, it was the same story all over again. I attributed it to playing more guitar than usual, but when laying off didnâ€™t help I thought I might have triggered arthritis. An x-ray was negative, though. What could it possibly be?

Then last night, while typing, I felt a twinge and looked down at my hands. It was blindingly obvious: I use emacs key mappings; the CTRL key is part of many of the basic chords; my poor left pinky is overloaded. Amping up the guitar playing probably pushed me over the edge, but it seems clear that is the root cause.

So Iâ€™m typing this post in order to adjust to yet another remapping. On this keyboard, thereâ€™s also a right CTRL key but itâ€™s not convenient to my right pinky, so Iâ€™ve recruited the right SHIFT key (which I apparently never use) to be my new CTRL key. Itâ€™s not going to be an easy adjustment, but I wonâ€™t complain, Iâ€™m just glad to know Iâ€™ve found the way forward.

Given these experiences, Iâ€™ve thought a lot about how we can unconsciously injure ourselves with repetitive and asymmetric patterns of movement. In my case, I donâ€™t seem to receive any signals until damage is already done. I wish I could notice sooner, do the necessary remapping, and continue with less disruption. But it just doesnâ€™t seem to work that way.

I really canâ€™t complain, though. Recently I met a guy in a guitar shop whose left wrist and hand became so painful that he had to switch sides and learn to fret with his right hand. Itâ€™s hard for me to conceive of doing that kind of remapping, but you do what you have to do. And as a bonus, heâ€™s now a switch-hitter: as he recovers some use of his left hand, he finds that he can achieve different effects as a right-handed and left-handed player.

Iâ€™m pretty sure Iâ€™ll get through this episode. The question will then become: how to avoid the next one? When we use computer keyboards or musical instruments, we need our hands to work unconsciously and automatically. Itâ€™s only when injuries happen that we have to surface whatâ€™s been unconscious, enter manual mode, and retrain until we can form new unconscious habits. I wish there were an early warning system.

18:36 • 22 days ago

Saturday, 22. July 2023

Rocco, Gregory

Party On, TCR Party

A Eulogy for a Game Family, friends, and fellow CT members, Today, we bid a heartfelt farewell to a beloved game that won our hearts in 2018, TCR Party. This game managed to carve a niche, transforming how we looked at token-curated registries, incentive models, and abstracted on-chain interactions. TCR Party was not just an ordinary game but a masterpiece of community spirit. As we r
A Eulogy for a Game

Family, friends, and fellow CT members,

Today, we bid a heartfelt farewell to a beloved game that won our hearts in 2018, TCR Party. This game managed to carve a niche, transforming how we looked at token-curated registries, incentive models, and abstracted on-chain interactions.

TCR Party was not just an ordinary game but a masterpiece of community spirit. As we remember and celebrate its existenceâ€Šâ€”â€Ša noble quest to curate a list of the 100 most influential Crypto Twitter accountsâ€Šâ€”â€Šit wasnâ€™t just about gaining followers or amassing likes, but about the friends we made along the way. Hell, we even got a CoinDesk article out of it (thanks, Leigh).

TCR Party: The #CryptoTwitter Popularity Contest Everyone's Talking About

TCR Party was not just about the numbers; it was about the people. Yet, as with all good things, the time has come to say goodbye to TCR Party. But let us not be saddened by its departure. Instead, let us cherish the memories of the camaraderie we shared, the knowledge we gained, and the impact it had.

Rest in peace, TCR Party. Your mark on the space shall never be forgotten.

Let me offer a brief introduction for those who don't know what any of this means.

Token Curated Registries (TCRs)

For those who are entirely new here, the first thing that should be explained are Token Curated Registries (TCRs).

TCRs were initially proposed by Mike Goldin as a way to have a decentralized set of actors essentially curate a list. This could be any form of informationâ€Šâ€”â€Šbe it something subjective such as a grocery list, a list of â€œnoteworthy projects,â€ or even a more enforceable registry such as an allowlist or blocklist for a forum.

Token-Curated Registries 1.0

Actions in this system involve nominating, voting, and challenging existing registry items, all controlled through token voting. The incentives and involved parties are structured as the following:

Self-interested curators (token holders) create a valuable list to increase the value of their voting power. Candidates that wish to be curated into â€œimportantâ€ lists would effectively buy or petition their way onto the registry. Consumers desire a trustworthy north star for curated information.

There are also additional incentive systems that keep people from making bad decisions, such as a failed nomination slashing the bond put in place to make that nomination in the first place. In this case, token holders are incentivized to keep the information on the list as noteworthy and â€œvaluableâ€ as possible to keep the system running and their holdings worth something.

But what makes information â€œvaluable?â€ Does it actually have to be truthful?

The Half-Truth in TCRs

Although TCRs set out to curate objective information for the sake of the value of the list, this is often marred by personal opinions, bribery, conspiracy, and plain old trolling. For a TCR to produce an objective list, you would need highly motivated specialists doing the curation that:

Care enough about the issue and have a wide enough audience to broadcast to, Are willing to put financial assets on the line in these cases, And are willing to morally be above bribery in the case of short-term payouts at the expense of more significant long-term gains.

I still think (considering the maturity of the technology and the general interest of folks) that TCRs arenâ€™t an excellent idea for curating meaningful, objective truth. This is why projects like Civil and TruStory were both dead on arrival.

In a wackier case, there was once even a proposal to name members voted onto a TCR as an oracle of an eventâ€™s outcome for a decentralized predictions market (in this case, not having a central reporting mechanism). However, due to a few more reasons around the scale of the event being reported on and plain old apathy, I wrote about this entire case a few years ago:

On TCRs and Predictions Markets: Counterweights and Collusion

In short, I donâ€™t believe TCRs can be helpful mechanisms for curating objective information. However, I believe they can play a part in making useful hyper-subjective lists, typically in art curation or even popularity contests. Subjectivity and opinions would make them practical for popularity contests because of how motivated people are in the case of low-stakes games for personal satisfaction. This is what sparked the idea for TCR Party.

TCR Party

I originally invented TCR Party while on the Alpine team at ConsenSys, led by Wayne Chang. I wanted to experiment with subjectivity and curation based on the above thesis.

My first thought was: â€œWhatâ€™s the most contentious, opinionated, and drama-filled place on the internet with a relevant audience?â€ The answer was Twitter. In this case, we would use the entirety of Crypto Twitter to curate a list of the top 100 Crypto Twitter accounts to follow. We would also call it â€œTCR Partyâ€ to give it an air of exclusivityâ€Šâ€”â€Šor a party you wished to be invited to.

TCR Party had to be abstracted, encourage subjective opinions, and fuel a popularity contest. One of the first things we did was abstract away any need to interface with wallets or a public blockchain directly by instead using Twitter as the primary user interface.

Twitter was typically where all crypto discourse was happening, and users were quite familiar with existing design patterns on the site. Therefore, we used bots to be both the relay for the curated list, and to handle all the interactions that involved public blockchains. I still wonder if it could be considered the first experiment in account abstraction because it used Twitter accounts to control wallets and handle transactions on your behalf.

How it Looked

The first step in the process was interfacing with the @TCRPartyVIP bot, which handled account generation and all on-chain actions on behalf of the user. This was initiated by Tweeting â€œHey @TCRPartyVIP letâ€™s party,â€ which would start the conversation with the bot. We figured this would initiate a fun viral feedback loop, where those who werenâ€™t sure what was going on would Tweet the same message to join in on what was happening.

After that, the bot would set up your account, and you can then start nominating, challenging, or voting using simple DMs to the bot, such as â€œnominate @exampleâ€ which would then initiate the action.

This bot was also responsible for continually posting updates about the on-chain activity. Any time there was a nomination, removal, or vote, the bot would Tweet the outcome or event as it happened.

We ultimately made the gameâ€™s asset inflationary to encourage continued participation (because voting with more strength required hitting the faucet daily). The bot would distribute 100 tokens daily if you told it â€œfaucet.â€ We went with the Rinkeby testnet at the time because it was simple to use and easy to minimize all the on-chain transaction costs. In this case, the user could always continue to play the game without worrying about funding the generated wallet. We did consider a world where the game was on mainnet, and users could essentially â€œejectâ€ from the system and control their own assetsâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut we felt it wasnâ€™t necessary at the time to carry out the experiment.

Finally, the game was centered on popularity for a reasonâ€Šâ€”â€Šit kept people coming back, and gave them the chance to be curated on a list alongside other popular accounts. For four years, @TCRPartyBot was responsible for amplifying each list member by retweeting any of their tweets. In this case, TCRPartyVIP could continue to post about challenges, nominations, and votes, while TCRPartyBot could be just the curation output.

The game ended up curating quite a decent list of characters over time, and even as the interest in TCR Party dried up, and we paused development on it, TCRPartyBot kept retweeting that list.

Not Dead Just Yet

The most important part of TCR Partyâ€™s development was making the contracts, leaderboard, Twitter bot, and even the website open source, so anyone can take TCR Party and make their own game.

All that would need to happen is a relaunch of all the components and someone to subsidize the testnet assets required to keep the machine running (or mainnet if someone is so generous). A new system launch would likely be smoother, considering how easy it is to spin up a new blockchain with enough speed and low enough cost to keep it simple.

I encourage anyone interested to pick it up and keep the party going. Who knowsâ€Šâ€”â€Šmaybe Iâ€™ll relaunch it.

Party on.

22:26 • 23 days ago

Moxy Tongue

Database-ism

 Database-ism * Seeing world through a view of structured data. * Defining one's self as data abstraction in req'd formats, fields, administrative contexts. * Reading "Rights" but accepting "Permissions" by service architecture. * $ID primary key as a database provisioned service and security method. * During administrative processing of data related to living experience, administrative proc

 Database-ism


* Seeing world through a view of structured data.
* Defining one's self as data abstraction in req'd formats, fields, administrative contexts.
* Reading "Rights" but accepting "Permissions" by service architecture.
* $ID primary key as a database provisioned service and security method.
* During administrative processing of data related to living experience, administrative process > human life  * "People" cloned as data structures based on language artifacts, rather than under local control authority of actual people, the bleeding kind. * Domination of human action in social-context where data is used to administer "people" authoritatively. * Ubiquitous allowance of data-based provisioning of human Rights as service permissions. * Artificial Intelligence modus operandi. *

Structure -> Results.. 
Read: Administrative Precedence

My Understanding of the JSON vs.JSON-LD

JSON, a Simple and Easy Start for Verifiable Credential Issuance  JSON is really really simple. It is just name value pairs. There is a tiny IANA registry for JWT claims that defines about 100 JSON terms. This is the one registry of JSON terms that folks who love JSON reference repeatedly and say solves any [â€¦] The post My Understanding of the JSON vs.JSON-LD appeared first on Identity Woma

JSON, a Simple and Easy Start for Verifiable Credential Issuance  JSON is really really simple. It is just name value pairs. There is a tiny IANA registry for JWT claims that defines about 100 JSON terms. This is the one registry of JSON terms that folks who love JSON reference repeatedly and say solves any [â€¦]

Misinformation Stops Here: W3C VC 2.0 Supports JSON

Misinformation sometimes gets a foothold and spreads across the digital identity oriented forums.  A most recent piece that is percolating is: the Verifiable Credential (VC) Data Model 2.0, which is under development within a formal W3C working group, does not or will not support JSON.  What is true:  W3C VC 2.0 is 100% capable of [â€¦] The post Misinformation Stops Here: W3C VC 2.0

01:00 • 25 days ago

Friday, 21. July 2023

reb00ted

Meta's plummeting Threads engagement numbers are good news for the Fediverse

The Wall Street Journal reports that: User engagement on Threads has continued to fall after an initial surge in sign-ups â€¦ the number of daily active users [has fallen] to 13 million, down about 70% from a July 7 peak, according to estimates from market intelligence firm Sensor Tower. The average time users spend on the iOS and Android apps has also decreased to four minutes from 19 minutes.

The Wall Street Journal reports that:

User engagement on Threads has continued to fall after an initial surge in sign-ups â€¦ the number of daily active users [has fallen] to 13 million, down about 70% from a July 7 peak, according to estimates from market intelligence firm Sensor Tower. The average time users spend on the iOS and Android apps has also decreased to four minutes from 19 minutes.

Thatâ€™s quite a bit different than the headlines of â€œfastest app growth in historyâ€ and â€œmore than 100 million accounts in a weekâ€. It was always clear that only a fraction of those initial users were going to stick around, but more concerning â€“ from Metaâ€™s point of view â€“ is that decrease in time spent with the app by the users that do continue to use the app: from 19 minutes to four minutes is a very significant decline.

From the perspective of the (open) Fediverse, however, I think this is very good news:

At these numbers, Threads is still significantly larger than the rest of the Fediverse combined, but far less so than it looked like a week ago. There was a possibility that Meta would simply drop their plans to implement ActivityPub, or just do a very rudimentary job, because why would you spend much attention on this if all you can connect to is a network 1% the size of your own. At 10-20%, as it looks like right now, that argument is very different. Rather than leaning back, and celebrating its success, Meta now needs to work hard to compete with Twitter. (And Twitter will have to compete back.) That is good for the world in general, and indirectly good for the Fediverse as the â€œmarketâ€ for text-based microblogs is suddenly competitive again. People realize they have at least two (well-marketed) choices; itâ€™s not a foregone conclusion that â€œTwitter owns thisâ€. If there are two choices, maybe there are three of four, including the non-Meta Fediverse. And perhaps, as a side effect of all of this, some of the dollars being spent may find their way into the Fediverse. Certainly Meta is now even more incentivized to highlight Threadsâ€™ differences with Twitter, and key to that is ActivityPub. I would think that should make them more willing, rather than less, to spend a bit of money on Fediverse infrastructure, like a test suite, that benefits the entire network. Of course, itâ€™s also good news for everybody who had been concerned that Threads would overwhelm the culture of the Fediverse the same way AOL overwhelmed in the culture of Usenet in the nineties.

(Note: I am in favor of Meta implementing ActivityPub in Threads; in fact I would like it to implement it in all of its social media properties, and messenger services like WhatsApp â€“ or perhaps a similar protocol like Matrix. I believe the same for non-Meta apps like LinkedIn, YouTube etc.

IMHO, the ability to interoperate across platforms is a major disinfectant, and can be a major factor in reducing product lock-in, which can lead to better products, more choices, and fewer â€œforcedâ€ policies like privacy invasions, because users have the ability to go elsewhere. I understand those Fediverse users who do not want to touch anything that Meta does and sympathize; the good news is that you, as a user, have unprecedented control in the Fediverse over who you do and do not want to interact with, and more power to you if you exercise that control.)

00:00 • 25 days ago

Thursday, 20. July 2023

Simon Willison

Prompt injected OpenAI's new Custom Instructions to see how it is implemented

Prompt injected OpenAI's new Custom Instructions to see how it is implemented ChatGPT added a new "custom instructions" feature today, which you can use to customize the system prompt used to control how it responds to you. swyx prompt-inject extracted the way it works: "The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they hav

Prompt injected OpenAI's new Custom Instructions to see how it is implemented

ChatGPT added a new "custom instructions" feature today, which you can use to customize the system prompt used to control how it responds to you. swyx prompt-inject extracted the way it works:

"The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have - this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests. Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is 'directly related, related, tangentially related,' or 'not related' to the user profile provided."

I'm surprised to see OpenAI using "quietly think about..." in a prompt like this - I wouldn't have expected that language to be necessary.

19:03 • 25 days ago

sqlite-vss v0.1.1 Annotated Release Notes

sqlite-vss v0.1.1 Annotated Release Notes Alex Garcia's sqlite-vss adds vector search directly to SQLite through a custom extension. It's now easily installed for Python, Node.js, Deno, Elixir, Go, Rust and Ruby ("gem install sqlite-vss"), and is being used actively by enough people that Alex is getting actionable feedback, including fixes for memory leaks spotted in production. Via @agar

sqlite-vss v0.1.1 Annotated Release Notes

Alex Garcia's sqlite-vss adds vector search directly to SQLite through a custom extension. It's now easily installed for Python, Node.js, Deno, Elixir, Go, Rust and Ruby ("gem install sqlite-vss"), and is being used actively by enough people that Alex is getting actionable feedback, including fixes for memory leaks spotted in production.

Via @agarcia_me

Jon Udell

A new series on LLM-assisted coding

In the 20th episode of my Mastodon series I pivoted to a new topic: LLM-assisted coding. After three posts in the new series, it got picked up by The New Stack. Hereâ€™s the full list so far, Iâ€™ll update it here as the series continues there. 1 When the rubber duck talks back 2 Radical â€¦ Continue reading A new series on LLM-assisted coding

In the 20th episode of my Mastodon series I pivoted to a new topic: LLM-assisted coding. After three posts in the new series, it got picked up by The New Stack. Hereâ€™s the full list so far, Iâ€™ll update it here as the series continues there.

1 When the rubber duck talks back

2 Radical just-in-time learning

3 Why LLM-assisted table transformation is a big deal

4 Using LLM-Assisted Coding to Write a Custom Template Function

5 Elevating the Conversation with LLM Assistants

Although Iâ€™ve spent decades working with software, and still regularly write code in one form or another, Iâ€™m only an average programmer. Thereâ€™s no doubt that LLM assistants can help me be better. But how much better? In what ways exactly? Thatâ€™s what I aim to find out. My day job embeds me in a fast-moving open-source project, Steampipe, to which I want to contribute as much as I can. That ambition was, until recently, tempered by my own limitations. Now, augmented by the collective knowledge embodied in LLM assistants, Iâ€™m raising my sights. Larry Wall famously said: â€œEasy things should be easy, and hard things should be possible.â€ Itâ€™s starting to look like even hard things can be easy. But the devilâ€™s in the details, so in this series Iâ€™ll focus on concrete examples of how LLM assistants do (and donâ€™t) help me become a better developer.

04:57 • 26 days ago

Simon Willison

Study claims ChatGPT is losing capability, but some experts arenâ€™t convinced

Study claims ChatGPT is losing capability, but some experts arenâ€™t convinced Benj Edwards talks about the ongoing debate as to whether or not GPT-4 is getting weaker over time. I remain skeptical of those claims - I think it's more likely that people are seeing more of the flaws now that the novelty has worn off. I'm quoted in this piece: "Honestly, the lack of release notes and transparency ma

Study claims ChatGPT is losing capability, but some experts arenâ€™t convinced

Benj Edwards talks about the ongoing debate as to whether or not GPT-4 is getting weaker over time. I remain skeptical of those claims - I think it's more likely that people are seeing more of the flaws now that the novelty has worn off.

I'm quoted in this piece: "Honestly, the lack of release notes and transparency may be the biggest story here. How are we meant to build dependable software on top of a platform that changes in completely undocumented and mysterious ways every few months?"
